## VSCode Setup (for the cool kids who don't want to use old-school Visual Studio 😎): It is possible to develop and build Conversation Service (CS) with VSCode instead of the regular Visual Studio. With VSCode you can still: - Build - Debug unit tests - Use IntelliSense - Detect C# warnings and errors And you get the lucrative benefits: - Full GitHub copilot support. (I know regular visual studio recently added support for this, but it is not the newest version that VSCode offers) - The full power of modern IDE features from VSCode like multiline editing, cool custom themes, and great source control UI - Custom extensions: support for things like GitLens can help you speed up workflows **But let me stress:** VSCode is not a full replacement for the original Visual Studio. There are still certain things that the original is better at, such as NuGet package management. Instead, I suggest using VSCode to augment daily development with modern productivity booster like custom extensions and the full version of copilot 🙂 1. Download and install VSCode: - [Stable](https://code.visualstudio.com/Download) - [Insiders](https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/) 2. Open the root folder in VSCode (for example: `C:/repos/sync_calling_concore-conversation/`) 3. Install the repo's suggested VSCode extensions: You should see a pop-up like this: ![Screenshot 2024-11-12 114635.png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/Screenshot%202024-11-12%20114635.png) Click `Show Recommendations` and install all shown in the list: ![image.png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/image.png) 4. You'll now see some new pop-up asking you to sign-in to some of the extensions. For the `C# Dev Kit`, sign in with your regular `@microsoft.com` account: ![Screenshot 2024-11-12 114752.png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/Screenshot%202024-11-12%20114752.png) For `GitHub Copilot`, sign in with your EMU account. (this will be your alias _microsoft. For example: `rthompson_microsoft`) ![image (2).png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/image%20%282%29.png) Note: please follow [steps here](https://repos.opensource.microsoft.com/orgs/MicrosoftCopilot) to activate copilot for you EMU account if you have not already. 5. Everything should be up and running now! Let's do a quick test to make sure you can build the solution. Press `shift + ctrl + p` to open the VSCode command palette and enter `.net: build`: ![image (3).png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/image%20%283%29.png) 6. Unlike regular Visual Studio which uses the file-menu for commands, VSCode relies heavily on the command palette. These are some useful commands to memorize: - `.Net: Build` - `.Net: Rebuild` - `.Net: Clean` - `Nuget: Update NuGet Package` -> Then enter `*` to select all projects. You can also open a full terminal inside of VSCode to do any missing commands that might be missing from the command palette by pressing: shift + ctrl + \` For example you might want to run `dotnet restore .\ConversationService\Microsoft.Skype.Calling.Conversation.sln` from the full terminal: ![image (4).png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/image%20%284%29.png) 7. The best part about all of this is Copilot! For a good intro please see here: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/overview But I like the entry point of highlighting code and then right-clicking: ![image (5).png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/image%20%285%29.png) 8. Unit testing support should work out of the box. Just click on the `Testing` tab and find the test you want to run: ![image (6).png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/image%20%286%29.png) 9. The `Deploy` & `ECS Defaults` projects can also be running for code gen through VSCode. Just click on the `Run and Debug` tab and select the project to run: ![image (7).png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1081823/attachments/image%20%287%29.png) ## VSCode Troubleshooting Here are some common errors that you might run into when getting VSCode to work: - ### `NuGet packages failing to install with a 401 status code or Failed to restore message` To fix these NuGet auth errors, please install the [Azure Artifacts Credential Provider](https://github.com/Microsoft/artifacts-credprovider#setup) by running this command: ```powershell iex "& { $(irm https://aka.ms/install-artifacts-credprovider.ps1) } -InstallNet8" ``` - ### `C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\9.0.200\NuGet.targets(175,5): error : Invalid character in the given encoding. Line 15, position 16.` For this error, please run all of the following steps: 1. Re-clone the repo for a fresh start. (Be sure to run `git submodule update --init --recursive` too) 2. In the newly cloned repo folder, run `dotnet nuget locals all --clear` 3. Next run `dotnet restore .\ConversationService\Microsoft.Skype.Calling.Conversation.sln --no-cache` If you still see **NuGet package** errors after this, open the freshly cloned repo inside of regular Visual Studio to restore and build it at least once. After the newly cloned repo builds successfully in regular Visual Studio, reopen it inside of VSCode and it should work! ### Other errors The above solutions fix most build issues, but if it's still not working for you, please confirm you have Visual Studio installed with these components: ![image.png](https://skype.visualstudio.com/e54c15f5-9715-4ec8-bf57-43fbd00fe57b/_apis/git/repositories/f295bac1-d87c-4aa5-8930-e88b50fe8244/pullRequests/1139982/attachments/image.png)
